data.title: Awards â€“ Society of Abdominal Radiology
data.text:
The Walter B. Cannon Medal was awarded annually to a distinguished radiologist who has made an outstanding contribution to the field of gastrointestinal and abdominal radiology, and the Society itself.

*In 2019, the Cannon Medal, Pollack Medal and Lifetime Achievement awards were transitioned to SAR Gold Medal awards.*

The Howard M. Pollack Medal was awarded annually to a distinguished radiologist who has made an outstanding contribution to the field of uroradiology and abdominal radiology, in addition to the Society itself. The Howard M. Pollack Medal is a continuation of the Gold Medal that was bestowed under the former Society of Uroradiology, with the last medal being bestowed under the SUR in 2012.

*In 2019, the Cannon Medal, Pollack Medal and Lifetime Achievement awards were transitioned to SAR Gold Medal awards.*

The Lifetime Achievement Award was bestowed upon any present or past member of the Society for his/her substantial contributions to abdominal radiology.

*In 2019, the Cannon Medal, Pollack Medal and Lifetime Achievement awards were transitioned to SAR Gold Medal awards.*

The Visiting Professorship Award is sponsored by Bracco Diagnostics, Inc. for SAR Members in the amount of $8,000. The SAR Igor Laufer Visiting Professorship is awarded each year to an outstanding abdominal radiologist who is an active member of the Society in good standing and who has demonstrated a history of contributions to the Society. These individuals are content experts and educational innovators in their respective field. They are dynamic speakers and demonstrate a passion for the educational pursuits of the Society. Past or present members of the Board are not eligible for this professorship.

The Richard H. Marshak International Lecturer Award is presented to a member of the SAR who will represent the Society in its international educational outreach. This award is in honor of Dr. Richard H. Marshak, a founding member and the first president of the former Society of Gastrointestinal Radiologists for his spirit of lectureship and dedication to the SGR. Recipients of this award are recognized as experts in the field of abdominal radiology and serve as an ambassador of the Society. An annual contribution of $4,000 is received from the Marshak Fund in support of this award.

The award honors an individual who is from outside North America and who has made an exceptional contribution to the field of, and a society promoting, abdominal, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary radiology. The recipient must be a current or past member of the SAR, SGR, SUR or a current or past member of one of the organizations with which the SAR has (or has had) a formal or informal relationship (currently, ESUR, ESGAR or ASAR).
